ref.title: “Harry and Lucy Concluded, Being the Last Part of Early Lessons, in Four Volumes, Vol 1”

div.head: Title
div.p: For volume 1 in MS I, volume 2 in MS III, and volume 3 in MS IIIA, Ruskin lettered the title pages in imitation of printed type. Compare the printed title page of Edgeworth, Harry and Lucy Concluded. Ruskinʼs title pages appear, respectively, as follows:

list.item: HARRY AND LUCY | CONCLUDED | BEING THE LAST | PART OF | EARLY LESSONS | [ornament] | in four volumes | vol I | with copper | [horizontal bar] | plates | [ornament] | PRINTED and composed by a little boy | and also drawn

div.p: See System of Title Citation for Works.

div.head: Genre
div.p: Composite work. Genre: lesson. Volume 1 also includes a travel account.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: Volume 1 of the work forms the principal contents of MS I (title page + pp. 1–96), a Red Book. This manuscript also contains “Poetry” [MS I Poetry Anthology].
MS II to come.
MS III to come.
MS IIIA to come.

div.head: Date
div.p: Volume 1, September or October 1826 through the end of the year, possibly extending into January 1827, although the opening portion of the work may have been composed, but not fair‐copied, during an earlier period.
Volume 2, to come.
Volume 3, to come.
See System of Date Citation.

div.head: Volume 1
div.p: Margaret Ruskin dated MS I as having been “begun about Sept or Oct 1826” and as having been “finished about Jany 1827”. Since she inserted this notation within “Poetry” [MS I Poetry Anthology] toward the end of the manuscript, it seems likely that Ruskin had devoted the latter part of this period—perhaps, December through January—to fair‐copying and/or composing the poetry anthology, while he had spent the fall of 1826 on “Harry and Lucy” (see also “The Needless Alarm”: Date; “On Papaʼs Leaving Home”: Date; and MS I: Date). It is also possible that, as suggested by a change in narrative style midway in the text of “Harry and Lucy”, Ruskin may have drafted the opening portion at an earlier period (see Discussion: Sources).

According to the narrative of Volume 1, while Harry and Lucy are visiting the seaside resort of Hastings, Harry identifies the fourth day of their visit as “the longest day”, a remark that Helen Gill Viljoen interpreted as referring to the summer solstice (which fell on June 21 in 1826 and on June 22 in 1827). Viljoen infers that Ruskinʼs composition date for Volume 1 must therefore be extended well past the terminus a quo of January 1827 established by Margaretʼs gloss on MS I to some time after June 1827 (“Dating MSS. of Boyhood”, in Viljoen Papers, boxes D.V, E.IX).

Viljoen discounted the possibility that Harryʼs remark refers to a holiday that, in real life, had already occurred, in June 1826, before Ruskin started work on MS I according to Margaretʼs gloss. She rejected this interpretation presumably on the grounds that the family could not have holidayed at the seaside in Hastings during June 1826, if they had already departed for Perth, Scotland, shortly after John Jamesʼs birthday on May 10. (W. G. Collingwood, not having noticed the clue about a “longest day”, assumed that the holiday must have preceded May 10 and occurred in “the spring of 1826” [Collingwood, The Life and Work of John Ruskin [1893], 1:25; The Life of John Ruskin [1900], 21].) It is now known, however, that the family must have delayed a vacation that year, since John James traveled for customer orders well past his birthday (see Tours of 1826–27). It is thus more plausible that, insofar as Ruskin drew on actual events that occurred at Hastings to help form his tale, he referred to a trip in the few months prior to when Margaret notes that he began work on MS I.

Greater uncertainty surrounds an alleged association of Volume 1 with a family journey north to Scotland in the autumn of 1826, an event that W. G. Collingwood drew from his reading of “On Scotland” in MS I and of “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Glen of Glenfarg thy beauteous rill”)) in MS III (see Tours of 1826–27). While such a scenario can be dovetailed with Margaretʼs dating of MS I by imagining Ruskinʼs starting the first volume of “Harry and Lucy” in “about Sept or Oct 1826” during the journey itself or shortly following the familyʼs return to Camberwell, it seems odd that the volumeʼs sole purported witness to a Scottish journey is a single poem, while Volume 2 of “Harry and Lucy,” written the following year in MS III, contains an extensive account of a visit to Perth. It is possible, of course, that Ruskin merely saved that material for the second volume. It is also possible that, as proposed in Tours of 1826–27, the family journeyed to Scotland only in 1827, not in 1826, and that the only recent travel available to Ruskin to describe in Volume 1 was the seaside visit that lay in the opposite direction, southward to Hastings.

div.head: Publication
div.p: Volume 1 previously unpublished in entirety. For his autobiography Praeterita (chap. 10), Ruskin ordered to be reproduced the conclusion of “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol I”, along with a drawing, “Harryʼs New Road”. These were reproduced in facsimile using type and engraving, in Ruskin, Works, 35:52–55.

Other prose excerpts from “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol I” are quoted in Collingwood, The Life and Work of John Ruskin (1893), 1:24–25; Collingwood, The Life of John Ruskin (1900), 21; and Hunt, Wider Sea, 34. Selected drawings from “Harry and Lucy . . . Vol I” are reproduced in Emerson, Genesis of Invention, pl. 2; and Walton, Drawings of John Ruskin, 6.

div.head: Volume 1
div.p: No draft survives of volume 1 of “Harry and Lucy” , but the text in MS I shows indications that it is a fair copy based on a lost draft. Given Ruskinʼs obsessive attention to the physical appearance of his text, it is not credible that he could have composed and fair‐copied the text simultaneously in this Red Book, MS I. He not only imitated his title page of Maria Edgeworthʼs Harry and Lucy Concluded; as indicated by the shapes of his characters in the text, he also modeled his printing on the serif typefaces used for that book as well as for Edgeworthʼs Frank; A Sequel, both of which were published by Baldwin, Cradock, and JoyorgName> (for Ruskinʼs copies of the published texts, see Books Used by Ruskin in His Youth: Physical Descriptions). He even adopted characters from the display typeface used for the title page of Edgeworthʼs Harry and Lucy Concluded to model decorative capitals used throughout his text (see also The Ruskin Family Handwriting: Ruskinʼs Early Print Lettering in Pencil). Further attesting to a lost draft, some of Ruskinʼs insertions in the fair‐copy text are most readily explained as correcting errors of transcription, not composition (see the textual glosses appended to the MS I witness in ERM).

Composition may have entailed two distinct stages of draft. While the four or five months comprised by Margaret Ruskinʼs dating of MS I could account for fair‐copying and perhaps some simultaneous drafting of “Harry and Lucy Concluded . . . Vol 1” and “Poetry” [MS I Poetry Anthology] (see Date of Composition: Volume 1), internal evidence suggests that chapter 1 of the prose narrative may be based on a distinctly earlier stage of composition. At the start of chapter 2, the narrative exhibits an abrupt shift from direct dialogue to third‐person narration. For the first time, a narrator addresses the reader, and the dialogue carries such tags as “said her mother” and “answered her father”. The shift in narrative method is accompanied by new characters appearing on the scene. In chapter 1, the dialogue is limited to Lucy and mother, whereas Papa is said to be away from home in the City. In chapter 2, Papa comes home, has a brief exchange with Lucy, and then, as the narrator informs us, “Lucy has gone to bed and we shall have time to attend to harry whose history we have hitherto forgot”. The sources behind subsequent exchanges—which tend to be three‐way between Papa, harry, and Lucy, excluding Mama—are are persistently identifiable as Edgeworthʼs Frank; A Sequel, and Harry and Lucy Concluded, whereas possible adaptations from these texts in chapter 1 are less certain. A likelier inspiration for chapter 1 may be the dialogues in Laetitia Barbauld's Evenings at Home.
As Christine Alexander has commented, in nineteenth-century imaginative accounts of childhood such as the bildungsroman, a child's voice is appropriated by an adult narrator; however, in nineteenth-century juvenilia, the reverse occurs: a child writer appropriates an adult voice. Child writers adopted "the freedoms of the adult world" by working "within a defined discourse" that they discovered in the print culture surrounding them. A typical resource was the nineteenth-century periodical, such as Blackwood's Edinburgh Magazine, which supplied the Brontë children with a range of discourses to imitate and adapt. By this means, child writers gave "an account of both their own and the adult world," and they empowered themselves to "construct an identity of authorship" chosen in "response to the print culture of their time" (Alexander, “Play and Apprenticeship”, 31). For Ruskin, the first prose discourse to serve this purpose was the genre of the lesson, as developed by Maria Edgeworth and others. Just as Charlotte and Branwell Brontë traded editorship of their own Young Menʼs Magazine, colonizing the adult discourses found in Blackwoodʼs Edinburgh Magazine, so Ruskin honed his powers of authorship by refashioning his surburban world of Herne Hill as dialogues between fictional interlocutors borrowed from Edgeworth and Jeremiah Joyce.
Similarly, in the material appearance of their manuscripts, the child writers appropriated and adapted the typography of the adult publications to their purposes. In the case of the Brontësʼ Young Menʼs Magazine, "their title pages actually looked like those of Blackwoodʼs, set out with elaborate colophons and publication details. They wrote editorial notes, contents pages, letters to the editor, advertisements, serialised stories, poems, reviews of paintings and books--all in minuscule script to imitate the print of Blackwoodʼs Edinburgh Magazine and signed by different fictitious Glass Town characters" (Alexander, “Readers and Writers”, 60). Ruskin, too, adhered closely to his adult model by basing his title page directly on Maria Edgeworth, Harry and Lucy Concluded; and while he did not write in a minuscule hand, he imitated typographic features in his print lettering. For example, he troubled to add serifs to many of his letters; and for many of his capitals, he drew a pillar-like, doubled vertical stroke that he called "double lettering." He also justified the margins of his prose text. In some places, he simply drew a vertical line to rule the margin nearest the gutter. In other places, he adopted the hyphen as a punctuation device to terminate a line at the justified right margin. In only approximately a half-dozen of these instances, however, did he employ the hyphen conventionally, as a sign for word division at the terminus of a line; rather, in the child writer's spirit of adaptation, he used the mark where no word was divided, but rather as a filler to take up blank space where his printing fell short of the ruled vertical margin. Despite these exacting contrivances, Ruskin does not imitate his print culture slavishly. He combines elements from varying models, supplying "plates" for Edgeworth's book, which was not originally illustrated, and he embellishes his version by adding a poetry anthology. Both on the title page and in the colophon, he adapts his imitations to his own world, in which the work is “composed by a little boy and also drawn,” and which is published at “hernhill” in an apparently fictitious “fountain street” (see MS I: Title and MS I: Discussion).
At the same time, the Brontësʼ adaptations of adult print culture present contrasts with Ruskin's, contrasts that correspond to differences between writing exchanged among a group of siblings and writing performed by an only child and presented to his parents. In Charlotte Brontëʼ Young Menʼs Magazine, devised as a "Second Series" when she took over editing of the family magazine from Branwell, and in Branwell's reply to the new series, "The Liar Detected," the sister and brother competed with one another and ridiculed the other's writing. Their jousting was in keeping with their model, Blackwoodʼs having made its mark with its satirical ribaldry by and between thinly veiled personae in such features as the "Noctes Ambrosianae." In this series of imaginary conversations, which ran between 1822 and 1835, and which was authored primarily by John Wilson (1785-1854), barbs were traded between Wilson as "Christopher North," William Maginn (1794-1842) as "Ensign O'Doherty," Thomas De Quincey (1785-1859) as the "Opium Eater," and James Hogg (ca. 1770–1835) as the "Ettrick Shepherd." Just as these personae vented spleen on one another and on other contemporary writers, while imbibing in "Ambrose Tavern," Charlotte used her "Conversations" in "Bravey's Inn" to mock Branwell's character, Young Soult, poet of Glass Town, who interrupts the exchange with his frothing verse, culminating in a fainting fit. Branwell parried in "The Liar Detected" by vilifying "unprincipled wretches who, having no caracter of their own to support and being too indolent to work, vilely employ their days in spitting their venom on every author of reputation within their reach." Such was Charlotte's persona, Lord Charles Wellesley, who, having raised himself to literary greatness on the admiration of "ladies of fashion," has now "forsooth" "stuck up a little magazine to instruct" these "young misses" (Brontës, Tales of Glass Town, Angria, and Gondal, ed. Alexander, 45-47, 317-18). In this "sibling rivalry which helped to fuel Charlotte's and Branwell's joint efforts," Carol Bock comments, "Blackwoodʼs satiric model of literary production and reception" served as an analogue, meeting "the personal needs of these two competitive young writers" and validating their rivalry, "by giving [their exchange] expression and cultural authority at the same time that [the analogue] displaced their competition from the problematic context of family to the safer arena of public life and professional experience" (Bock, “‘Our Plays’”, 49).
By comparison, in volume 1 of "Harry and Lucy," Ruskin's Harry and Lucy converse in harmonious exchange, presumably because both characters present uniform extensions of the single self of this solitary child writer. It is only with the arrival at Herne Hill of Ruskin's cousin, Mary Richardson, that the voices of Ruskin's fictional personae diverge and contest one another.
His writing is up to date: by the time he began his own version in 1826, Edgeworthʼs text, which was first published in 1825, cannot have been in the household for very long. Presumably, by this time, Ruskin also knew at least some of the previous volumes of Edgeworthʼs “Early Lessons,” such as Frank (Edgeworth, Works, 12:169–237), a copy of which survives among (Ruskinʼs boyhood books).
As Ruskinʼs writing progresses, it swerves from creative adaptation to nearly verbatim copying from the Scientific Dialogues of Jeremiah Joyce. (The plagiaristic change occurs most noticeably at the point at which Ruskinʼs characters Harry and Lucy follow their father “upstairs to the workshop,” where they engage in a series of experiments drawn directly from the Dialogues [Joyce, Dialogues, [chap. 2].) Joyceʼs work consists of “conversations” between a girl Emma, a boy Charles, and their father (and, at times, between two boys, Charles and James, and their tutor). Joyce closely follows the Edgeworthsʼ educational theories and their genre of the lesson, attributing his bookʼs interlocutional method to Edgeworth, Practical Education (Edgeworth, Works, vol. 11) as the most effective means of communicating ideas to children and gauging their intellectual progress. More exclusively and technically focused on scientific topics than the Edgeworthsʼ lessons, however, the Scientific Dialogues aim at systematically introducing young readers to the major fields of scientific knowledge.
It is in keeping with these sources that Ruskin, in the “Poetry” [MS I Poetry Anthology] which follows “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, starts off the collection with “When furious up from mines the water pours” [“The Steam Engine”]—a poem derived from lines by Erasmus Darwin that versify similar interests in scientific probing. Darwin and the Edgeworths were associated with the Lunar Society, which advocated scientific exploration, especially as applied to practical industrial progress. Thus, Ruskinʼs earliest surviving writing is derived from study of works celebrating Enlightenment scientific and industrial entrepreneurship.
Even if they were not plagiarized from Joyce, dangerous experiments involving exploding gunpowder and specialized scientific apparatus would be obviously fictional, but Ruskin did carry out some Edgeworthian projects at Herne Hill. Like Harry, he built a “cave” in May 1826 (Ruskin Family Letters, 149; see chaps. 4–5 of “Harry and Lucy,”), and the story of Harryʼs mud globe has the sound of reality (chap. 9), although one cannot be sure.
More in keeping with this spirit of adaptation rather than rote copying, chapter 1 and the first part of chapter 2 of “Harry and Lucy,” seem original and based on actual experience (with the exception of the unlikely exchange about silkworms). The dialogue is nonetheless based on the kind of discourse found in Edgeworthʼs books, such as the passage in which Ruskin has the Mamma exploit a task of winding balls of silk thread in order to quiz Lucy on the multiplication tables. Ruskin seems to relate vivid, everyday experiences with his mother, who, one might speculate, tutored her son using the educational techniques advocated in Practical Education. Thus, Ruskinʼs “Harry and Lucy” possibly was art imitating life imitating art. (Servants, however, make no appearance at all, not even Ruskinʼs nurse, Ann Strachan, important as she was to him (see, e.g., Ruskin Family Letters, 109).
Personalities and situations in the text seem somewhat modeled on real impressions, as well. The fictional Mamma in “Harry and Lucy,” is methodical, insistent on “do[ing] one thing at once,” a character suggestive of Margaret Ruskin, who tended to spy dangers in any behavior, even opposed behaviors, that failed to be regulated by “principles” (e.g., Ruskin Family Letters, 98, 100). At the same time, Margaret was probably communicating the methodicalness recommended by educators. The parents in Edgeworthʼs Early Lessons are likewise measured in their approach, the mother saying to a child that she will answer questions at her leisure, and only if the child minds and remembers the answer; and the father checking overly eager inquiry, since “thinking, without tiring ourselves, is very agreeable; but thinking becomes disagreeable, if we tire ourselves.” Frank is frequently exhorted to save until later what he cannot comprehend immediately (Edgeworth, Works, 12:). In Joyceʼs Dialogues, procedures are systematic and graduated, starting with simpler concepts in mechanics and astronomy (vol. 1), and progressing through hydrostatics and pneumatics (vol. 2), and finally optics, magnetism, electricity, and galvinism (vol. 3). Thus, in her letters, when Margaret attempts to order Johnʼs (and his fatherʼs) play by insisting that he finish one project before taking up another (e.g., Ruskin Family Letters, 187), her methodicalness is in keeping with Edgeworthʼs advice to balance the spirit of inquiry with management of the gradations of difficulty.
As suggested in Composition and Publication, Maria Edgeworthʼs lessons, while best known for encouraging children to learn through their own observation and discovery, in fact depicted a complex dynamic of observation with memory. Frank learns to analyze a passage of verse by Erasmus Darwin by observing for himself in nature the phenomena that Darwin describes using both poetic metaphor and exact naturalistic description. The culmination of the lesson, however, is Frankʼs recitation of the verse, learned “by rote” from the printed text (Edgeworth, Works, 12:195–203); the verse is from The Botanic Garden, part 2 (‘The Loves of the Plants’), canto 1 (Darwin, Poetical Works, 2:2–3).
Yet if Ruskin has his fictional Mamma adopt this methodical approach, he himself is not so easily restrained. In “Harry and Lucy,” in response to Mammaʼs declaration, “Well I think we have had thought enough for the present,” Lucy returns “just two or three questions” more (chap. 1). Defying Joyceʼs system, Ruskin puts his Harry and Lucy in the middle of the curriculum—Harry, the text declares, “must begin with pneumatics,”—and even within that advanced topic, Ruskinʼs text works generally backwards through Joyceʼs series of experiments, starting with most advanced. While Ruskinʼs Harry does appear to grasp the central purpose of Joyceʼs experiments in pneumatics—that they are meant to investigate atmospheric “pressure and springiness,” as Harry puts it (chap. )—Joyce and the Edgeworths would have expected the seven-year-old Ruskin to work his way gradually through experiments appropriate to his age, such as Frankʼs exploration of the more fundamental concept of experimentation generally, using the homely trial of testing for effective ways to mend a broken saucer (see Frank, part 2, in Maria Edgeworth, Frank, 1:123–31). Instead, Ruskinʼs determination to have his own way with the system is not only precocious, but enamored of spectacle. He seems to relish the fancier hardware in Joyceʼs later chapters, and consequently sacrifices preparatory concepts.
This precocious behavior was not necessarily so much resistant as energetic. In Margaretʼs letters about Ruskinʼs behavior leading up to 1826, while she does discuss discipline (especially during Ruskinʼs first three years), she more frequently remarks his “busy” activity and “chatting” (as well as attentive listening) (e.g., Ruskin Family Letters, 108, 116, 126, 128). The sheer bustle of his precocious writing and drawing was also probably directed at managing his fatherʼs absences on business. In “Harry and Lucy,” it is striking that the episodes copied from Joyce center on the father character, whereas Edgeworthʼs lessons for younger children, like Barbauldʼs, engage father and mother equally in the conversational method. The respective prominence of father or mother, in Edgeworth as in Ruskin, is to an extent a function of the early Victorian household. In Edgeworthʼs lessons for younger children, such as Frank, the boy and his mother are necessarily often together; and just so, in Ruskinʼs earlier chapters, his Harry and Lucy must appeal to Mama since “papa has gone out to town” (chap. 1). John James Ruskin, however, as the traveling partner of his firm, spent especially long weeks away from home, and his son became caught up in Margaretʼs anxieties for John Jamesʼs safety and health. Ruskin may even have attributed his fatherʼs absences to a guilty sense of own “bad” behavior (e.g., Ruskin Family Letters, 109, 116). It is perhaps not surprising, then, that Ruskin would have used precocious writing in some sense to conjure his fatherʼs presence.
That this desire drove Ruskin especially in his copying of text beyond his years was registered by Margaret when John, soon after completing “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, and MS I, produced what she called his “first written letter” (either meaning the first letter he wrote himself, as opposed to dictating, and to be sent to his Papa directly, or meaning the first letter he wrote in longhand—or both). Margaret observes: “I believe the showing you his writing occupied his thoughts fully more than how he expressed his feelings so you must excuse that,” as “he is much delighted at being able to use pen & ink” (Ruskin Family Letters, 156). Just as Edgeworth urges her child characters to use their “own little eyes” in dynamic relation with (not necessarily in opposition to) learning “by rote,” Ruskin copies dialogues with Papa at the end of “Harry and Lucy” because the performance was, for him, related, not opposed, to the absent father at the start who “fear[s] I shall not have time” to hear Lucyʼs lesson (chap. 2).
If Ruskinʼs text exhibits impatience with Joyceʼs system, his verbal and pictorial illustrations reveal a steady advance in the writerʼs ability to represent complex relationships. In the “plates” at the beginning of MS I, which are among the earliest surviving drawings by Ruskin, objects are lined up on a single plain, but later plates attempt more complex spacial relationships. Similarly, in verbal terms, the first portion of the narrative lines up events in simple sequences, whereas, toward the end, the representation of journeying inspires a more serpentine and surprising description like this one: “they climbed a high hill and went on sometimes by the sides of rivulets at other times half rubbing against hedges but oftenest so attracted by the bubbling of a pure clear stream that they were like to jump into it they went through dark avenues and between hedges forming a sort of foot-path sometimes a full view of the sea sometimes none at all till unexpectedly they arrived at home” (chap. 8). Apropos of this increasing sophistication, the experiments from Joyce, which are clustered in chapters 8 and 9, may have interested Ruskin because of the language required to explain multiple and complex causal relationships.
At the end of his adaptation, Ruskinʼs imitation culminates in a tour de force combining science and poetry—Joyceʼs Dialogues and Byronʼs Manfred—in Harryʼs “witch of the alps” fantasy (chap. 10), which Ruskin made famous by reproducing in facsimile in Praeterita. Poetry is not alien to Edgeworthʼs lessons, and Joyce ornaments his dialogues with verse quotations, but their improving works are more apt to quote Erasmus Darwin than Byron. Ruskin does adapt Darwin for part of the “Poetry” [MS I Poetry Anthology] (see “When furious up from mines the water pours” [“The Steam Engine”]: Discussion). But in Harryʼs vision closing “Harry and Lucy,” Ruskin goes beyond the verse ornamentation of scientific prose to reveal a keen consciousness of the pleasures of crossing genres, for Harry is “affected” by witnessing “in the clouds something like” an image from a poem.
What “affects” Harry is possibly psychological as well as literary. For Ruskin, Harry and Lucyʼs adventures at a seaside resort like Hastings would have represented a joyful release from a period of grief and loneliness earlier in the year. Business had kept Ruskinʼs father from home for an unusually extended period, and a fatal illness had deprived the boy of his cousin James Richardsonʼs companionship forever (see “On Scotland”). This deprivation may have influenced Ruskinʼs decision to imitate the Edgeworthsʼ partnership of Harry and Lucy. Not only would the fictional pairing have compensated him for losses; their activities together could have played out and controlled in fiction what Ruskin could not control in life—as when Lucy is made to bide the time, first, of a busy father, and, immediately afterward, of a preoccupied brother (chap. 2).
Some episodes in “Harry and Lucy” seem particularly poignant and psychologically suggestive, such as the childrenʼs kidnapping their mother and imprisoning her in Harryʼs “cave,” where she must attend to one of Harryʼs “schemes,” a procession of birds (chaps. 4–5). Fantasy may also enter into the concluding “witch of the alps” episode with its spectral female form. The passage, with its exchange of negative and positive electrical discharges, might be read as an attempt to control and neutralize some sort of trouble.

div.head: Thematic Differences
div.p: This text is the start of a projected adaptation of Edgeworth, Harry and Lucy Concluded (see Discussion), which Ruskin meant, according to his title page, to extend to four volumes (see Title). Ultimately, the project reached only three volumes (“Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1; “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2; and “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 3), with the third volume itself left unfinished. Ruskin was generally correct, therefore, when he wrote in Praeterita that the series is unfinished, although he inaccurately accuses himself of having “accomplished but one and a quarter” volumes (Ruskin, Works, 35:52). Possibly this mistake arose because Ruskin did not have at hand all the Red Books containing “Harry and Lucy,” an oversight evidenced by his having notated in 1870 only three of the notebooks as “No. 1,” “No. 2,” and “No. 3.” Of these, only Red Book No. 3 (MS I) and Red Book No. 2 (MS III) contain “Harry and Lucy,”—volumes 1 and 2, respectively, of the work—and since volume 2 takes up only 21 of the 82 numbered pages in MS III, it seems clear that Ruskin mistakenly figured one volume plus a quarter based on an incomplete reckoning of the Red Books.

Differing kinds of composition may be suggested by physical evidence. At points where Ruskin copies nearly verbatim from a source, Joyce, Scientific Dialogues (see Discussion), the text abruptly shows the kind of errors associated with transcribing (e.g., words stricken through, because the writer has inadvertently omitted text and must reinsert it). Such text starts with the discussion about silkworms.

Despite this physical evidence, copying and invention were as dynamically related as they were opposed in Ruskinʼs development as a writer. First, copying was how Ruskin learned to write. In 1823, Margaret Ruskin remarked that “he is beginning to copy from his books and will soon learn himself to write I think,” and at this point Ruskinʼs most legible writing consisted of his signature, which he presumably learned by imitation. Second, copying was integrated within the dynamic of writing by the family as a whole. As his so-called first letter, Ruskin dictated to his mother, who wrote “word for word what he pretended to read from his paper” (Ruskin Family Letters, 128). Third, imitation was a significant feature of educational methods of the time, but such practices did not necessarily train only rote memory: see Discussion.

div.head: Travel
div.p: In the second half of “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 1, the characters visit the seaside resort of Hastings for a week, apparently recording an actual summer journey (see Date). At the start of “Harry and Lucy,” Vol. 2, Ruskin locates his characters at Hastings still, dovetailing the two volumesʼ adventures, although the second volume was not begun until fall or winter 1827.
